'''Kaltura''' is a [[software company]] based in [[New York]] which was founded in 2006.<ref name="urlConversation with Kaltura Founder Ron Yekutiel | CenterNetworks"/>
Kaltura's technology allows publishers and content owners to publish, manage, monetize and analyze their video and other rich-media content. The main components of Kaltura's online video platform are based on [[open-source]] software, enabling any site to add advanced video and rich-media capabilities.
==Concept== The original concept was built on the collaborative [[Wiki]] model but uses media rather than text. Over time, the company changed its focus to providing an open source video platform with a focus on universities, enterprises, media companies and service providers looking to deploy video in their organizations.
Publishers can add video capabilities using Kalturaâs hosted services, download the open source community edition, deploy the platform on-premise behind their own firewall, or on the cloud (such as Amazon Web Services). Kaltura also provides self-serve video packages for web-platforms such as [[MediaWiki]], [[WordPress]], [[Drupal]], [[Joomla]], etc.
==History== Kaltura was founded in the fall of 2006 by Ron Yekutiel (CEO as of 2008), Dr. Shay David (VP of Community and Business Development as of 2008), Dr. Michal Tsur (a co-founder of [[Cyota]], President and COO as of 2008) and Eran Etam (a co-founder of [[ICQ]], Kaltura's CTO as of 2008).<ref>http://corp.kaltura.com/about/leadership (accessed August 6, 2008)</ref>
Kaltura was launched at the [[TechCrunch40]] industry event in San Francisco on September 18, 2007, and won the Peopleâs Choice award based on a vote of the conference's attendees.<ref name="tc07">Mark Hendrickson: [http://www.techcrunch.com/2007/09/18/kaltura-wins-spot-as-40th-company-at-techcrunch40/ Kaltura Wins Spot as 40th Company at TechCrunch40] [[TechCrunch]], September 18, 2007</ref> At that time, the company had 20 employees, and had received 2.1 million dollars in funding from [[business angel]]s and Californian [[Venture capital|VC fund]] ''Avalon Ventures''.<ref name="tc07"/>
On December 21, 2007, Kaltura won the Peopleâs Choice award (over 250,000 users participated in voting) in the Video Sharing category for the [[Mashable]] Open Web Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2007/12/21/open-web-awards-winners/|date=2007-12-21|title=Open Web Awards: Final Winners Announced!|publisher=[[Mashable]]}}</ref> Also in 2007, Kaltura began a partnership with the [[New York Public Library]], whose team was headed by [[Joshua Greenberg]]. In 2008, Kaltura was selected as one of the "Global 250 Winners" by [[AlwaysOn]].<ref>[http://alwayson.goingon.com/permalink/post/27959 ''AO Global 250 Winners''] July 17, 2008</ref> Kaltura CEO and cofounder Ron Yekutiel was photographed for the article "The Suit, Vers. 3.0" in [[Esquire Magazine]]'s July 2008 edition.<ref>[http://www.esquire.com/style/fashion-story/suits-0708 The Suit, Version 3.0] ''Esquire Magazine'' online, July 7, 2008</ref>
In January 2008, the [[Wikimedia Foundation]] and Kaltura announced that they had begun a collaboration aimed at bringing rich-media collaboration to [[Wikipedia]] and other wiki websites.<ref>[http://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Wikipedia_Invites_Users_to_Take_Part_in_Open%2C_Collaborative_Video_Experiment Wikipedia Invites Users to Take Part in Open, Collaborative Video Experiment]. Wikimedia press release, January 17, 2008</ref> The technology behind this project is a form of [[video-wiki]] software (open source and still in beta) that is integrated into the [[Mediawiki]] platform as an extension, allowing users to add collaborative video players that enable all users to add and edit images, sounds, diagrams, animations and movies in the same manner as they do today with text.
Kaltura was a sponsor of the [[Wikimania 2008]] event, where it announced that it is sponsoring Michael Dale, an open source video developer, to support the further development of a 100% open source video editing solution integrated into MediaWiki.<ref>http://blog.wikimedia.org/2008/07/23/kaltura-sponsors-michael-dale-open-source-video-developer/</ref>
In addition to support of MediaWiki, Kaltura enables interactive videos integrated within popular CMS and blogging platforms such as [[WordPress]].
Kaltura is also a founder of the Open Video Alliance, a group of organizations, academics, artists and entrepreneurs, geared towards promoting open standards for video on the web.
== Products == {{Expand section|date=August 2008}} Kaltura products include video players, video editors (including a collaborative video editor), a [[content management system]], a [[WordPress]] [[Plug-in (computing)|plugin]], a [[Drupal]] module, a [[Mediawiki]] extension, and [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]] and [[PHP]] frameworks. In essence, according to the company's website, Kalturaâs open-source video management platform enables organizations to deploy applications that involve video creation, ingestion, publishing, management, syndication, engagement, monetization and analysis. Kalturaâs free community-supported self-hosted software and source-code is available at www.kaltura.org. A commercial version of the software can be obtained at www.kaltura.com along with Kaltura services such as rich media streaming, hosting, transcoding, analytics, ad serving, support and maintenance packages, and professional development. Kalturaâs Application Exchange enables software and service providers to market solutions that are integrated with Kalturaâs API.
